blog.cmpxchg8b.com

You don’t need reproducible builds.

I’m skeptical about build reproducibility, but ardent supporters are defending and cheering for it at every opportunity. After a few too man...

Note:

@InsanityBit Yes, there are reasonable non-security reasons you might want it, I'm only opposed to the security arguments.

link_counts.title: Tavis Ormandy: You don’t need reproducible builds.

posts.cooked:
Very interesting and educational.
The most interesting part of the article I find is this-

  • Q. Whether it’s useful for end users or not, it will allow experts to monitor for compromised build servers producing tampered builds.

I think this is true, but there are other attacks against compromised build servers, all of which are more common than producing tampered builds.

More often, attackers want signing keys so they can sign their own binaries, steal proprietary source code, inject malicious code into source code tarballs, or malicious patches into source repositories.

Reproducible builds don’t help with any of those problems.

Here in this part of the article it brings up an interesting point that the writer does not explore or instead chooses to avoid. Which is in my own words “Majority of users will not compile directly from source code, but some experts may”.
In the the article the author states-

“What isn’t clear is what benefit the reproducibility provides. The only way to verify that the untrusted binary is bit-for-bit identical to the binary that would be produced by building the source code, is to produce your own trusted binary first and then compare it. At that point you already have a trusted binary you can use, so what value did reproducible builds provide?”

Then the author goes on to state-

“The answer to this question is that reproducible builds are not for users, they are expected to nominate somebody they trust to build it for them, and verify that the output is correct.”

Now the author does not consider that some users could be highly technically skilled individuals, and may compile from source code themselves to then use the trusted binaries to compare all the untrusted binaries of all the vendors to see if he gets one which does not match his. Yes it is true that majority of users will not compile directly from source, and will not compare binaries from the vendors, but the fact that it is possible to do so means that attackers and malicious vendors pose the risk of being caught out. Doing this sort of attack on a large scale to multiple users increases the risk of being caught out, which can prompt the attackers to only use this kind of attack method on a selective number of users to avoid being caught, therefore possibly taking the attack out of the scope of mass surveillance and bringing it more into the scope of targetted surveillance.
Anyway I like the article, and I am glad that the author does not deny the validity of one of the points raised to him.
Nice read!

I am currently reading-

reproducible-builds.org

Reproducible Builds — a set of software development practices that create an...

Reproducible builds are a set of software development practices that create an independently-verifiable path from source to binary code.

link_counts.title: Reproducible Builds — a set of software development practices that create an independently-verifiable path from source to binary code
An attempt to backdoor the kernel [LWN.net]
Security researcher pleads guilty to hacking into Microsoft and Nintendo - The Verge

posts.cooked:
His main argument is simple, and I find it quite convincing:
If you take the source code, of, for instance, Signal, and copy it on your computer. Then you build your own binary. Afterwards, you get the Signal apk from the Google Play Store and those two versions are compared bit for bit to see, whether the are identical or not.
Now, his point:
If you already made your apk from source code, why caring about the Google Play version at all? You have a trusted version and you are done!

New here in the forum. No Signal user yet, but maybe someone can convince me to switch. Who knows?

boom42:

New here in the forum. No Signal user yet, but maybe someone can convince me to switch. Who knows?

Just a random brainfart - but I think you might not need convincing. You already have a reason for being here, likely some form of interest. Just install it and play around with it. It’ll likely convince you

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
boom42:

and those two versions are compared bit for bit to see, whether the are identical or not.

That is not how it works. The apk can be opened as a zip file. The reproducible build now checks if the files in the zip are identical, except for the signing files that you can’t compare because you don’t have Signals apk signing key. That are 3 files in META-INF.

boom42:

If you already made your apk from source code, why caring about the Google Play version at all? You have a trusted version and you are done!

In some cases there are components used that need API keys, so even if you can build your own app, unless you go to the trouble of also getting your own API keys, not all features will work.

posts.name: Markus Ottela
posts.cooked:
boom42:

If you already made your apk from source code, why caring about the Google Play version at all? You have a trusted version and you are done!

Well you can find out if you’re a person of interest to some intelligence establishment that would try to server you a backdoored binary via Play Store.

Also, chance of getting caught prevents Google from modifying the distributed binaries.

Getting caught once in either case will most likely bring attention to the topic causing surge in users checking their binaries.

Finally, if community work would be put into it, having a WoT build binaries, publish authentic signed hashes etc. would allow you to check the validity of the distributed binary with a one-liner that obtains the APK from your phone, hashes it, and compares it against the (authenticated) signed signature.

The thing is, there’s different amounts of certainty in “trust the vendor blindly” and “trust nobody has found anything”. It’s enough one finds a bugdoor or backdoor, and everyone can very easily see it’s there and the amount of work needed to understand is significantly reduced, than if every user would have to audit the code to be able to trust it. Surely, we might end up in situation where everyone assumes someone else has found it, but direct gain of trusting the app oneself or obtaining money and fame via bug bounty do motivate people to look into it, and we’ve already seen experts like JPA et. al. look into the code.

So to rephrase: Their findings benefited every Signal user, and reproducible builds are a way to check that the fixes indeed made their way into the distributed binary for everyone else. If not, it only takes one user to spot their client uses different version than the one where the bug is patched.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
maqp1:

would allow you to check the validity of the distributed binary with a one-liner that obtains the APK from your phone, hashes it, and compares it against the (authenticated) signed signature.

That is no absolute check against running a backdoored version. If an attacker with local root odexes the installed Signal the apk remains the same but the changed, odexed code will run on the phone. That’s the same method Lucky Patcher uses to bypass some checks in paid apps to run them on any device, or to remove advertisements from an app.

posts.name: Markus Ottela
posts.cooked:
johanw666:

If an attacker with local root odexes the installed Signal the apk remains the same but the changed, odexed code will run on the phone

Endpoint exploitation is different from backdoored cryptography implementation, and outside the threat model of Signal. If you need security from endpoint exploitation, TFC is the only thing that has stronger guarantees than generic hardening. But even that has problems that can not be addressed, the most important being if your endpoint always gets compromised (e.g. with a rootkit) when you download the application, it’s not possible to obtain software from secure communication and thus unless it’s preinstalled, it’s not possible to have secure communication on said platform in the first place.
Is everything in the apk reproducibly built? So many 3rd party components are downloaded in binary form and Signal’s own native libraries are also not built on your side.

johanw666:

That is not how it works. The apk can be opened as a zip file. The reproducible build now checks if the files in the zip are identical, except for the signing files that you can’t compare because you don’t have Signals apk signing key. That are 3 files in META-INF.

Don’t get lost in technical details.
Ormandy is completely right to say the following:
If you really want to be sure, that an apk you get from Google Play is identical with the binaries you obtain by making the apk yourself, is to compare it byte for byte.
If there is no way to do such a comparison, then you can’t be sure, that the Google Play version of an app is identical.
And if you want to compare them, and you start with creating your own binaries from source, you don’t need to proceed.

As said, I don’t know Signal, it’s more a general thing, which applies.

If byte for byte comparisons are not possible, then you can’t ever be sure, that the Google Play version is really the one you wanted to have.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
boom42:

Don’t get lost in technical details.

If ypu don’t want to know the details, don’t keep talking about the byte for byte comparison because tnat will show up differences anyway, even when the source is built from the same sources.

Just adding my bit to this thread on a topic which has my interest…

I’ve read Tavis’s article and the other posts here.

From my point of view, it’s like this:

  1. How do I know the open source code available on GitHub is the one used to produce the app on the store? Reproducible builds allow me to verify this. Now, I can do this because a) I’m tech-savvy and b) I’m an Android developer. But what about people who are neither of these. This brings us to point 2

  2. If you don’t know how to do the above, maybe you know someone who does. For example, my friends (who I evangelised to Signal to and are now Signal users) are neither sufficiently technical or Android developers. But they trust me and I told them I could reproduce the builds and this was good enough for them. But what if you don’t know someone who can verify the builds? This brings us to point 3.

  3. If you don’t know someone who can verify the build, the very fact that the build is reproducible in the first place and that anybody can verify it as such and, crucially, nobody has flagged that the builds don’t match means that the build from the store can be trusted. The very absence of a claim from anyone anywhere that the builds don’t match is really enough to trust the build. Since it stands to reason that someone somewhere would have checked. This means that situations in 1 and 2 are only extra assurances but aren’t strictly necessary.

I hope I’m clear enough.

An old topic and one which I hope is not really up for debate but, in case anyone is interested, the argument for reproducible builds is made beautifully on the reproducible builds website.

reproducible-builds.org

Reproducible Builds — a set of software development practices that create an...

Reproducible builds are a set of software development practices that create an independently-verifiable path from source to binary code.

One very strong argument which never occurred to me before:

“Reproducible Builds protect developers from targeted attacks by allowing third-party verification of their software, preventing your projects from being compromised.”
